text: Number 436, Frank Grumman, Petitioner, versus United States.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
He made a pertinency before?
Oh, yes, he did.
After --
Yes, he --
-- (Inaudible)
-- he made a pertinency objection by saying, "I don't think that the question is pertinent".
He is sapient?
Well, that's their terminology.
Then why -- why was it peculiar about the language?
Well, it's peculiar because I don't know that they have a classification.
Well, they have pigeonholes in which they put witnesses --
Yes.
-- in advance.
That's correct, in advance.
Where is it in your brief?
6 to 7.
6 to 7.
I'm sorry.
We'll recess now, Mr. --
Thank you, Your Honor.
What are the indictments alleged that the subject under inquiry was?
It didn't allege anything, Your Honor.
Well on the previous case, in the Yellin case, the indictment did allege in some specific detail of the subject under inquiry.

Well, we have briefed in our brief and I won't have time to get into it, that the Government in the District of Columbia has adopted the practice of never alleging the subject under inquiry or never alleging pertinence.
Well in here --
-- both of those problems.
-- in this case you don't know what the theory of the grand jury was, do you?
Well, I don't know.
Do you ask -- do you ask for a bill of particular?
Yes, I did Your Honor.
(Inaudible)
Yes.
Did you take an exception for that?
Well, it's not -- I'm sure it's preserved in the record without the necessity of taking exception under our procedure.
Now, let me just -- you -- you were to concede with.Sure that was just an indirect way of asking him whether he'd been in those conference meetings.
I don't concede.
(Voice Overlap)
In fact but let's assume that.
It's an --
Let's assume --
alternate way of --
the question --
-- stating that question.
Whether he was at communist meetings in 1936 to 1940.
You think the Committee is bound by this statement (Inaudible)?
The Committee is not bound by it, as a matter of fact that -- it wasn't.
And you can't any further, you can't cross-examine and can't go to find out whether he's telling the truth?
Well, let's put it this way, if the Committee is not interested and -- and the Staff Director there has made it perfectly clear, not only under the annual report reflects that.
Mr. Terris.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
All those are three separate --
Well, the first two are quite -- are -- are really -- are really the same thing.
(Inaudible)
That's right.
I noticed on footnote 33 on page 108 of brief that you --
That was not a holding.
-- exchanged your positions?
Yes, that is not a --
As to what Markham case holds?
No, that is not a holding.
Now, in Shelton, it was represented to us that was a holding and in --
There was a mistake.
-- Markham case, it was not.
There was a mistake, Your Honor.
Instead, you've given us the two tests by which the sufficiency of an indictment isn't measured according to your position, would they be any different with respect to an information?
I would think so.
-- well then what's the deference between -- what's -- what's the purpose then in requiring an indictment?
Well --
-- there any further additional test applicable --
You go to a grand jury.
-- to an indictment which are not applicable to an information?
Well, there's -- there's one of course additional protection for the defendant.
What's that?
They goes -- they go to a grand jury and the grand jury supposedly --
And the grand jury supposedly indicts somebody for his specific offense?
That's right.
Well, his first argument is that the indictment should -- that the grand jury should have said what the subject was.
Well, that's part of why they're pertinent.
Well, but this -- his first step --
Okay.
-- would be based --
Okay.
-- should have said identified the subject.
Okay.
Why was it made below (Inaudible)?
I -- it was -- it was raised before trial, Your Honor.
Mr. Terris, how -- how was the grand jury informed with the pertinency of -- of these questions?
Your Honor, I've -- I have no way of knowing -- I assume --
Doesn't it need to be?
I would -- yes -- yes, I -- I -- just because we don't have it -- the transcript of the grand jury testimony, I don't know.
Well, suppose the grand jury was thinking of pertinency and in one light and the -- the trial jury was thinking of it in another light.
That's --
Would -- would you -- would they be prosecuting him for the same offense that the grand jury was charging?

Well, You honor, I submit that that's a danger which the -- this Court's -- the trend of this Court's decisions leave possible, the idea that you don't have to specify every detail that has -- that's going to be proved.
What do you take that to mean that requirement if it is one that the Committee must not utilize indiscriminate dragnet procedures on some of the witnesses?
I would think that they cannot call somebody off the street and say, "Dude, what do you know about communism?"
Would they be very likely to do something like that?
No, no, they wouldn't.
It's alleged in the Shelton case that they did something fairly close to that.
It was alleged, Your Honor but I think that -- but the Government's position at least --
Yes.
-- was that the facts were quite different.
Is that the extent of the dragnet definition?

Well, I don't want to say that that's the full extent but it seems to me that -- that Barenblatt and the other cases stand for the proposition that -- that this Court and the other federal courts have to presume that Congress of the United States is -- is acting lawfully and that they will not have a full scale inquiry into whether it had justification, probable cause as you will or -- or the --
You mean there's a -- are -- are you suggesting that the indiscriminate dragnet means that it would violate that principle if you did not have probable cause to subpoena the witness?
No, I did I -- I tried to answer Mr. Justice Stewart --
Well, I --
-- by saying that --
-- you tru but you haven't --
To say that --
-- for me that what's you think.
The clear cases if they have no information.
But couldn't that be a legitimate inquiry?

As I read the -- the Barenblatt and the -- and of course this is picked up to some extent in Wilkinson and Braden that although that might have reasonableness that this may -- might well be how an investigator would proceed, that the important First Amendment Rights which are being weighed and I think contrary to petitioners that -- that this Court in those three cases gave very great weight to the First Amendment Right and weighing those important rights that -- that there had to be some more basis than the fact that anybody in that stables.
Well, that's not the point but what's the basis?
No, I don't -- I don't --
Well, then but less than problem where you're phrasing?
I think I'd rather take with the -- the Court's phrasing Your Honor.
And if I would oppose -- like the opposite of lacking improbable causes but you have probable cause.
Well, one of the difficulties is that -- that words often mean something -- different words than their -- depending on their context.

If you -- unless you can point to some constitutional provisions, I find it difficult to follow the idea that a grand jury or a committee that has full power to investigate this matter can prohibit this from summoning everybody it want to summon.
I think I -- well, Your Honor, I think that is the basic principle.
Was this witness represented at that time?
Oh, yes.
Can he ask questions?
He may not ask questions.
He cannot raise and object to a question.
No, he -- he is entitled --
He can't --
-- to whisper in his -- in his --
He can't address the Chairman?
The rules say not but -- but it is so -- as long as the -- the colloquy doesn't go on too long if that the -- the rules seems to be -- not to be honored too well.
Well, the customary thing is the counsel for petitioner would then apply to --
Right.
-- (Inaudible) which yourself know or believe which was (Inaudible).
That's right.
